app Package#

This section covers the modules within the app package, which handles the web application’s frontend, layout, callbacks, and utilities.

Main Application#

Dash is a framework for building analytical web applications. No JavaScript required.

If a parameter can be set by an environment variable, that is listed as:

env: DASH_****

Values provided here take precedence over environment variables.

param name:

The name Flask should use for your app. Even if you provide your own server, name will be used to help find assets. Typically __name__ (the magic global var, not a string) is the best value to use. Default '__main__', env: DASH_APP_NAME

type name:

string

param server:

Sets the Flask server for your app. There are three options: True (default): Dash will create a new server False: The server will be added later via app.init_app(server)

where server is a flask.Flask instance.

flask.Flask: use this pre-existing Flask server.

type server:

boolean or flask.Flask

param assets_folder:

a path, relative to the current working directory, for extra files to be used in the browser. Default 'assets'. All .js and .css files will be loaded immediately unless excluded by assets_ignore, and other files such as images will be served if requested.

type assets_folder:

string

param pages_folder:

a relative or absolute path for pages of a multi-page app. Default 'pages'.

type pages_folder:

string or pathlib.Path

param use_pages:

When True, the pages feature for multi-page apps is enabled. If you set a non-default pages_folder this will be inferred to be True. Default None.

type use_pages:

boolean

param include_pages_meta:

Include the page meta tags for twitter cards.

type include_pages_meta:

bool

param assets_url_path:

The local urls for assets will be: requests_pathname_prefix + assets_url_path + '/' + asset_path where asset_path is the path to a file inside assets_folder. Default 'assets'.

type asset_url_path:

string

param assets_ignore:

A regex, as a string to pass to re.compile, for assets to omit from immediate loading. Ignored files will still be served if specifically requested. You cannot use this to prevent access to sensitive files.

type assets_ignore:

string

param assets_external_path:

an absolute URL from which to load assets. Use with serve_locally=False. assets_external_path is joined with assets_url_path to determine the absolute url to the asset folder. Dash can still find js and css to automatically load if you also keep local copies in your assets folder that Dash can index, but external serving can improve performance and reduce load on the Dash server. env: DASH_ASSETS_EXTERNAL_PATH

type assets_external_path:

string

param include_assets_files:

Default True, set to False to prevent immediate loading of any assets. Assets will still be served if specifically requested. You cannot use this to prevent access to sensitive files. env: DASH_INCLUDE_ASSETS_FILES

type include_assets_files:

boolean

param url_base_pathname:

A local URL prefix to use app-wide. Default '/'. Both requests_pathname_prefix and routes_pathname_prefix default to url_base_pathname. env: DASH_URL_BASE_PATHNAME

type url_base_pathname:

string

param requests_pathname_prefix:

A local URL prefix for file requests. Defaults to url_base_pathname, and must end with routes_pathname_prefix. env: DASH_REQUESTS_PATHNAME_PREFIX

type requests_pathname_prefix:

string

param routes_pathname_prefix:

A local URL prefix for JSON requests. Defaults to url_base_pathname, and must start and end with '/'. env: DASH_ROUTES_PATHNAME_PREFIX

type routes_pathname_prefix:

string

param serve_locally:

If True (default), assets and dependencies (Dash and Component js and css) will be served from local URLs. If False we will use CDN links where available.

type serve_locally:

boolean

param compress:

Use gzip to compress files and data served by Flask. To use this option, you need to install dash[compress] Default False

type compress:

boolean

param meta_tags:

html <meta> tags to be added to the index page. Each dict should have the attributes and values for one tag, eg: {'name': 'description', 'content': 'My App'}

type meta_tags:

list of dicts

param index_string:

Override the standard Dash index page. Must contain the correct insertion markers to interpolate various content into it depending on the app config and components used. See https://dash.plotly.com/external-resources for details.

type index_string:

string

param external_scripts:

Additional JS files to load with the page. Each entry can be a string (the URL) or a dict with src (the URL) and optionally other <script> tag attributes such as integrity and crossorigin.

type external_scripts:

list of strings or dicts

param external_stylesheets:

Additional CSS files to load with the page. Each entry can be a string (the URL) or a dict with href (the URL) and optionally other <link> tag attributes such as rel, integrity and crossorigin.

type external_stylesheets:

list of strings or dicts

param suppress_callback_exceptions:

Default False: check callbacks to ensure referenced IDs exist and props are valid. Set to True if your layout is dynamic, to bypass these checks. env: DASH_SUPPRESS_CALLBACK_EXCEPTIONS

type suppress_callback_exceptions:

boolean

param prevent_initial_callbacks:

Default False: Sets the default value of prevent_initial_call for all callbacks added to the app. Normally all callbacks are fired when the associated outputs are first added to the page. You can disable this for individual callbacks by setting prevent_initial_call in their definitions, or set it True here in which case you must explicitly set it False for those callbacks you wish to have an initial call. This setting has no effect on triggering callbacks when their inputs change later on.

param show_undo_redo:

Default False, set to True to enable undo and redo buttons for stepping through the history of the app state.

type show_undo_redo:

boolean

param extra_hot_reload_paths:

A list of paths to watch for changes, in addition to assets and known Python and JS code, if hot reloading is enabled.

type extra_hot_reload_paths:

list of strings

param plugins:

Extend Dash functionality by passing a list of objects with a plug method, taking a single argument: this app, which will be called after the Flask server is attached.

type plugins:

list of objects

param title:

Default Dash. Configures the document.title

(the text that appears in a browser tab).

param update_title:

Default Updating.... Configures the document.title

(the text that appears in a browser tab) text when a callback is being run. Set to None or ‘’ if you don’t want the document.title to change or if you want to control the document.title through a separate component or clientside callback.

param background_callback_manager:

Background callback manager instance to support the @callback(..., background=True) decorator. One of DiskcacheManager or CeleryManager currently supported.

param add_log_handler:

Automatically add a StreamHandler to the app logger if not added previously.

param hooks:

Extend Dash renderer functionality by passing a dictionary of

javascript functions. To hook into the layout, use dict keys “layout_pre” and “layout_post”. To hook into the callbacks, use keys “request_pre” and “request_post”

param routing_callback_inputs:

When using Dash pages (use_pages=True), allows to

add new States to the routing callback, to pass additional data to the layout functions. The syntax for this parameter is a dict of State objects: routing_callback_inputs={“language”: Input(“language”, “value”)} NOTE: the keys “pathname_” and “search_” are reserved for internal use.

param description:

Sets a default description for meta tags on Dash pages (use_pages=True).

param on_error:

Global callback error handler to call when an exception is raised. Receives the exception object as first argument. The callback_context can be used to access the original callback inputs, states and output.

Layout#

Main layout definition for the ThermogramForge application.

Defines the structure and components of the user interface using Dash Bootstrap Components and Dash Core Components. Includes the main tab structure, data overview section, review endpoints section (with grid, plots, control panel), upload modal, and data stores.

app.layouts.main_layout.create_layout()[source]#

Creates the main layout container with all UI elements.

Defines the overall structure including header, tabs (Overview, Review), modals, and necessary dcc.Store components for holding application state.

Returns:

The root Dash Bootstrap Container for the app layout.

Return type:

dbc.Container

app.layouts.main_layout.register_layout(app)[source]#

Registers the layout with the Dash app instance.

Assigns the layout created by create_layout() to the app.layout attribute.

Parameters:

app (Dash) – The Dash application instance.

Callbacks#

Callbacks for ThermogramForge.

This package contains callback definitions for the application.

app.callbacks.init_callbacks()[source]#

Initialize all callbacks.

Callbacks related to baseline parameter selection, adjustment, and application.

This module includes:

  • Callbacks to handle user interaction for selecting/adjusting baseline endpoints:

    • Clicking the thermogram plot (handle_endpoint_click_ag).

    • Directly editing flags (Reviewed, Exclude) in the AG Grid (update_flags_from_grid).

  • UI helper callbacks (e.g., toggling advanced options).

app.callbacks.baseline_callbacks.update_flags_from_grid(cell_change_data, all_saved_params, selected_filename)[source]#

Updates the main baseline-params store when ‘Reviewed’ or ‘Exclude’ is changed in the AG Grid.

Parameters:

  • cell_change_data (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Dictionary provided by AG Grid on cell value change. Contains row data, column ID, and new value.

  • all_saved_params (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]]]) – The current state of the main baseline parameter store.

  • selected_filename (Optional[str]) – The filename of the currently active dataset.

Return type:

Union[Dict[str, Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]], NoUpdate]

Returns:

The updated baseline parameter store dictionary or no_update if change is invalid.

app.callbacks.baseline_callbacks.toggle_advanced_options(toggle_value, is_open)[source]#

Toggles the visibility of the advanced options section in the upload modal.

Parameters:

  • toggle_value (List[int]) – List containing the value of the switch (1 if checked, empty otherwise).

  • is_open (bool) – The current open/closed state of the collapse component.

Return type:

bool

Returns:

The new state for the is_open property of the collapse component.

app.callbacks.baseline_callbacks.handle_endpoint_click_ag(raw_click_data, processed_click_data, current_selection_mode, current_temp_params_store)[source]#

Handles clicks on EITHER the raw or processed thermogram plot.

Updates the temporary baseline parameters based on the clicked temperature and the active selection mode (‘lower’ or ‘upper’). Also updates the endpoint display values and resets the selection mode and button colors.

Parameters:

  • raw_click_data (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Data from the raw plot click event.

  • processed_click_data (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Data from the processed plot click event.

  • current_selection_mode (Optional[str]) – The active endpoint selection mode (‘lower’ or ‘upper’).

  • current_temp_params_store (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – The current dictionary stored in temporary-baseline-params.

Return type:

Tuple[Union[Dict[str, Any], NoUpdate], Optional[str], Union[str, NoUpdate], Union[str, NoUpdate], str, str]

Returns:

A tuple containing updates for relevant components.

Callbacks for the main control panel, dataset selection, and review workflow.

Handles interactions within the ‘Review Endpoints’ tab, including: - Populating the control panel based on the selected sample. - Triggering review mode from the ‘Data Overview’ tab. - Toggling the upload modal. - Activating endpoint selection mode via buttons. - Handling ‘Discard Changes’, ‘Mark Reviewed & Next’, ‘Previous Sample’ buttons. - Loading data into the AG Grid for the selected dataset. - Saving processed metadata. - Updating UI elements like overviews and statuses.

class app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.ControlPanelOutputs(style, title, lower_display, lower_source, upper_display, upper_source, exclude_value, exclude_disabled, cancel_disabled, select_lower_disabled, select_lower_color, select_upper_disabled, select_upper_color, mark_reviewed_disabled, previous_sample_disabled)#

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.update_control_panel_on_selection(selected_rows, baseline_data, selected_filename)[source]#

Updates the control panel when a grid row is selected or baseline data changes.

Determines the appropriate state for all control panel elements based on whether a valid sample is selected and its corresponding baseline parameters are available.

Parameters:

  • selected_rows (Optional[List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – Data for the selected row in the AG Grid.

  • baseline_data (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]]]) – The main baseline parameter store.

  • selected_filename (Optional[str]) – The filename of the currently active dataset.

Return type:

ControlPanelOutputs

Returns:

A ControlPanelOutputs namedtuple containing the state for all output components.

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.handle_review_button_click(n_clicks)[source]#

Switches to Review tab and selects the corresponding dataset.

Triggered when a ‘Review Endpoints’ button is clicked on the Data Overview tab.

Parameters:

n_clicks (List[Optional[int]]) – List of click counts for all buttons matching the pattern.

Returns:

  • The target tab ID (‘tab-review’).

  • The filename (index) of the dataset to select in the dropdown.

Return type:

A tuple containing

Raises:

PreventUpdate – If no button click triggered the callback or if the triggered button ID cannot be parsed.

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.toggle_upload_modal(n_open_overview, n_open_review, n_close, is_open)[source]#

Opens or closes the upload modal based on button clicks.

Parameters:

  • n_open_overview (Optional[int]) – Click count for the overview tab’s upload button.

  • n_open_review (Optional[int]) – Click count for the review tab’s upload button.

  • n_close (Optional[int]) – Click count for the modal’s close button.

  • is_open (bool) – Current state of the modal’s is_open property.

Return type:

bool

Returns:

The new state for the modal’s is_open property (True to open, False to close).

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.activate_endpoint_selection(lower_clicks, upper_clicks, current_mode)[source]#

Activates/deactivates plot click mode for endpoint selection.

Sets the endpoint-selection-mode store to ‘lower’, ‘upper’, or None. Highlights the active button with ‘warning’ color.

Parameters:

  • lower_clicks (Optional[int]) – Click count for the lower endpoint button.

  • upper_clicks (Optional[int]) – Click count for the upper endpoint button.

  • current_mode (Optional[str]) – The current value in the endpoint-selection-mode store.

Returns:

  • The new selection mode (‘lower’, ‘upper’, or None).

  • The color for the lower selection button (‘primary’ or ‘warning’).

  • The color for the upper selection button (‘primary’ or ‘warning’).

Return type:

A tuple containing

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.discard_sample_changes(n_clicks, selected_rows, baseline_data, selected_filename)[source]#

Resets control panel and temporary params to the last saved state.

Retrieves the parameters for the selected sample from the main baseline-params store (for the active dataset) and updates the control panel display fields and the temporary-baseline-params store accordingly. Also resets selection mode.

Parameters:

  • n_clicks (Optional[int]) – Click count for the discard button.

  • selected_rows (Optional[List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – Data for the selected row in the AG Grid.

  • baseline_data (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]]]) – The main store containing saved baseline parameters.

  • selected_filename (Optional[str]) – The filename of the currently active dataset.

Returns:

  • Lower endpoint display text.

  • Lower endpoint source text.

  • Upper endpoint display text.

  • Upper endpoint source text.

  • Exclude checkbox value.

  • Lower button color (reset).

  • Upper button color (reset).

  • Endpoint selection mode (None).

  • Temporary baseline parameters store (reset to saved values or None).

  • Alert message text.

  • Alert visibility (True).

  • Alert color (‘warning’).

Return type:

A tuple containing updates for

Raises:

PreventUpdate – If button not clicked, no row/dataset selected, or data missing.

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.handle_mark_reviewed_next(n_clicks, selected_rows, temp_params_data, exclude_checkbox_value, grid_data, baseline_data, selected_filename)[source]#

Saves changes for the current sample, marks as reviewed, and selects the next sample.

Retrieves parameters from the temporary store, updates the main baseline-params store for the active dataset, updates the corresponding row in the grid’s rowData, and advances the grid selection.

Parameters:

  • n_clicks (Optional[int]) – Click count for the button.

  • selected_rows (Optional[List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – Data for the currently selected row.

  • temp_params_data (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Data from the temporary-baseline-params store.

  • exclude_checkbox_value (bool) – Current value of the exclude checkbox.

  • grid_data (Optional[List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – Current rowData of the AG Grid.

  • baseline_data (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]]]) – The main baseline parameter store.

  • selected_filename (Optional[str]) – Filename of the active dataset.

Returns:

  • baseline-params store.

  • sample-grid rowData.

  • sample-grid selectedRows.

  • Alert message text.

  • Alert visibility.

  • Alert color.

Return type:

A tuple containing updates for

Raises:

PreventUpdate – If button not clicked or required data is missing.

  • selected_rows (Optional[List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – Data for the currently selected row.

  • grid_data (Optional[List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – Current rowData of the AG Grid.

  • Alert message text.

  • Alert visibility.

  • Alert color.

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.save_processed_data_to_store(n_clicks, all_samples_data, saved_baseline_params, raw_filename, existing_processed_data)[source]#

Saves the final reviewed baseline parameters to the processed data store.

Generates the key based on the raw filename and current date. Marks the corresponding raw dataset as processed.

Parameters:

  • n_clicks (Optional[int]) – Click count for the save button.

  • all_samples_data (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, List[Dict[str, Any]]]]]) – The main store containing raw data for all datasets.

  • saved_baseline_params (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]]]) – The main store containing reviewed baseline parameters.

  • raw_filename (Optional[str]) – The filename of the raw dataset being reviewed.

  • existing_processed_data (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – The current state of the processed data store.

Returns:

  • processed-datasets-store.

  • Alert message text.

  • Alert visibility.

  • Alert color.

  • Active main tab (switches to overview on success).

Return type:

A tuple containing updates for

Raises:

PreventUpdate – If button not clicked or required data is missing.

Handles both datasets saved from the review process and those uploaded directly.

processed_datasets (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – The store containing metadata about processed datasets.

List[ListGroupItem]

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.update_raw_data_status(processed_datasets, status_id)[source]#

Updates the status display (‘Processed’/’Not Processed’) for raw datasets.

Checks if a raw dataset filename (from the component ID’s index) exists as a source_raw_file value within the processed-datasets-store.

Parameters:

  • processed_datasets (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – The dictionary stored in processed-datasets-store.

  • status_id (Dict) – The dictionary ID of the html.Small component being updated. Contains {“type”: “raw-status”, “index”: <filename>}.

Returns:

‘Processed’ or ‘Not Processed’.

Return type:

The status string

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.load_data_for_review(selected_filename, baseline_data)[source]#

Loads AG Grid data when a dataset is selected for review.

Constructs rowData for the grid based on the baseline parameters for the selected dataset filename. Triggers selection of the first row. Also updates the message below the dataset selector.

Parameters:

  • selected_filename (Optional[str]) – The filename selected in the dataset dropdown.

  • baseline_data (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]]]) – The main baseline parameter store.

Returns:

  • List of dictionaries for the grid rowData.

  • A trigger value (timestamp) for select-first-row-trigger.

  • An informational message for the selector alert.

  • Visibility state for the selector alert.

  • Color for the selector alert.

Return type:

A tuple containing

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.select_first_grid_row(trigger_value, grid_data)[source]#

Selects the first row in the grid when the trigger store changes.

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.update_download_filename_placeholder(selected_raw_filename)[source]#

Updates the placeholder text for the download filename input.

Takes the selected raw filename, removes the extension, and appends _processed_[DDMMYYYY].csv.

Parameters:

selected_raw_filename (Optional[str]) – The filename selected in the review dataset dropdown.

Return type:

str

Returns:

The generated placeholder string.

app.callbacks.control_panel_callbacks.download_processed_data_csv(n_clicks, processed_datasets, all_samples_data)[source]#

Handles clicks on ‘Download Data’ buttons for processed datasets.

Generates a wide-format CSV with interpolated, baseline-subtracted data.

Parameters:

  • n_clicks (List[Optional[int]]) – List of click counts for all buttons matching the pattern.

  • processed_datasets (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – The store containing processed dataset metadata and parameters.

  • all_samples_data (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – The store containing raw sample data and upload metadata.

Return type:

Optional[Dict]

Returns:

A dictionary suitable for dcc.Download, or None if no button was clicked or data is missing.

app.callbacks.upload_callbacks.process_upload_multi_sample(is_completed, store_baseline_params, store_all_samples_data, filenames, upload_id, min_temp, max_temp, lower_exclusion, upper_exclusion, selection_method)[source]#

Processes an uploaded thermogram file (CSV or Excel).

Extracts samples, filters by temperature, calculates initial baseline parameters, updates the main data stores (all-samples-data, baseline-params). Only performs processing when triggered by the dash-uploader component completion.

Parameters:

  • is_completed (bool) – Flag from dash-uploader indicating if upload finished.

  • store_baseline_params (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Current state of the baseline parameters store.

  • store_all_samples_data (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Current state of the raw sample data store.

  • filenames (Optional[List[str]]) – List of uploaded filenames from dash-uploader.

  • upload_id (Optional[str]) – Upload ID from dash-uploader.

  • min_temp (Optional[float]) – Minimum temperature selected in the modal.

  • max_temp (Optional[float]) – Maximum temperature selected in the modal.

  • lower_exclusion (Optional[float]) – Lower exclusion temperature from modal (unused currently).

  • upper_exclusion (Optional[float]) – Upper exclusion temperature from modal (unused currently).

  • selection_method (Optional[str]) – Point selection method from modal (unused currently).

Returns:

  • Updated baseline parameters dictionary for the store.

    • Updated raw sample data dictionary for the store.

    • Content for the upload status alert.

Returns no_update for store outputs if not triggered by uploader or on error.

Return type:

A tuple containing

app.callbacks.upload_callbacks.build_raw_data_overview(all_samples_data, _baseline_params, processed_datasets_store)[source]#

Builds the list group item display for the raw data overview.

Parameters:

  • all_samples_data (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – The store containing raw data and metadata keyed by filename.

  • _baseline_params (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – The store containing initial baseline params (unused for status now).

  • processed_datasets_store (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Store containing final processed data keyed by generated name.

Return type:

List[ListGroupItem]

Returns:

A list of dbc.ListGroupItem components.

app.callbacks.upload_callbacks.update_raw_data_overview_ui(all_samples_data, baseline_params, processed_datasets_store)[source]#

Updates the list group display for raw files when data stores change.

List[ListGroupItem]

Callbacks related to thermogram visualization.

This module defines functions for creating Plotly figures for raw and processed thermogram data and includes callbacks triggered by user interactions like selecting a dataset, selecting a sample from the grid, changing plot tabs, and updating temporary baseline parameters via plot clicks.

app.callbacks.visualization_callbacks.create_raw_thermogram_figure(df_raw, title='Raw Thermogram', baseline_params=None)[source]#

Creates a Plotly figure for the raw thermogram data.

Parameters:

  • df_raw (Optional[DataFrame]) – DataFrame containing the raw thermogram data with columns ‘Temperature’ and ‘dCp’. Can be None or empty.

  • title (str) – The title for the plot.

  • baseline_params (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Dictionary containing baseline parameters (‘lower’, ‘upper’, ‘lower_source’, ‘upper_source’) to draw vertical lines and annotations. Can be None.

Return type:

Figure

Returns:

A Plotly Figure object representing the raw thermogram.

app.callbacks.visualization_callbacks.create_processed_figure(df_processed, baseline_params=None, title='Baseline Subtracted Thermogram')[source]#

Creates a Plotly figure for the baseline-subtracted thermogram data.

Parameters:

  • df_processed (Optional[DataFrame]) – DataFrame containing the processed data with columns ‘Temperature’, ‘dCp_subtracted’. Can be None or empty.

  • baseline_params (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Dictionary containing baseline parameters (‘lower’, ‘upper’, ‘lower_source’, ‘upper_source’) to add endpoint annotations. Can be None.

  • title (str) – The title for the plot.

Return type:

Figure

Returns:

A Plotly Figure object representing the processed thermogram.

app.callbacks.visualization_callbacks.update_dataset_selector_options(all_samples_data, current_value, previous_options)[source]#

Updates the dataset selector dropdown options and selects newly added dataset.

Parameters:

  • all_samples_data (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – The main store containing data for all uploaded files (datasets).

  • current_value (Optional[str]) – The currently selected value in the dropdown.

  • previous_options (Optional[List[Dict[str, str]]]) – The previous list of options in the dropdown.

Returns:

  • A list of dictionaries for the dropdown options.

  • The value for the dropdown (newly added dataset or current if still valid).

Return type:

A tuple containing

Shows or hides the review panel based on dataset selection.

  • selected_dataset (Optional[str]) – The filename of the dataset selected in the dropdown.

  • current_style (Optional[Dict]) – The current style dictionary of the review content area.

Returns:

  • A message for the alert below the selector.

  • A boolean indicating whether the alert should be open.

  • The updated style dictionary for the review content area.

Return type:

A tuple containing

app.callbacks.visualization_callbacks.update_plots_on_grid_row_select(selected_rows, all_samples_data, saved_baseline_params, selected_filename)[source]#

Update plots, active tab, and visibility when a row is selected.

Generates raw and processed plots based on saved baseline parameters. Sets the active plot tab to ‘tab-processed’ and updates plot div styles.

Parameters:

  • selected_rows (Optional[List[Dict[str, Any]]]) –

    …

  • all_samples_data (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, List[Dict[str, Any]]]]]) –

    …

  • saved_baseline_params (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]]]) –

    …

  • selected_filename (Optional[str]) –

    …

Returns:

  • Plotly figure for the raw thermogram.

  • Plotly figure for the processed thermogram.

  • The active plot tab ID (always “tab-processed”).

  • Style dictionary for the raw plot container (hidden).

  • Style dictionary for the processed plot container (visible).

Return type:

A tuple containing

app.callbacks.visualization_callbacks.update_stores_on_grid_row_select(selected_rows, saved_baseline_params, selected_filename)[source]#

selected_rows: … saved_baseline_params: … selected_filename: …

Return type:

Optional[Dict[str, Any]]

Dictionary of baseline parameters for the selected sample (or None).

app.callbacks.visualization_callbacks.reset_selection_mode_on_grid_row_select(_selected_rows)[source]#

Resets the endpoint selection mode whenever a new grid row is selected.

This ensures that clicking the grid cancels any active endpoint selection.

Parameters:

_selected_rows (Optional[List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – Input trigger (value not used).

Returns:

Always resets the endpoint-selection-mode store to None.

Return type:

None

app.callbacks.visualization_callbacks.update_raw_plot_from_temp_params(temp_params_data, all_samples_data, selected_filename, current_raw_figure_dict, current_processed_figure_dict)[source]#

Updates BOTH raw and processed plots when temporary baseline parameters change.

Triggered after a user clicks on a plot to set a new endpoint. Retrieves raw data, redraws the raw plot with updated annotations, recalculates the baseline subtraction using temporary params, and redraws the processed plot.

Parameters:

  • temp_params_data (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Dict from temporary-baseline-params store.

  • all_samples_data (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]]) – Main data store containing samples and metadata.

  • selected_filename (Optional[str]) – Filename of the currently selected dataset.

  • current_raw_figure_dict (Optional[Dict]) – Current state of the raw plot figure dict.

  • current_processed_figure_dict (Optional[Dict]) – Current state of the processed plot figure dict.

Return type:

Tuple[Union[Figure, NoUpdate], Union[Figure, NoUpdate]]

Returns:

Tuple containing updated figures for the raw and processed plots, or no_update.

app.callbacks.visualization_callbacks.handle_plot_tab_change(active_tab)[source]#

Shows/hides plot divs based on active tab.

Does NOT regenerate any plots.

Parameters:

active_tab (str) – The ID of the currently active plot tab (‘tab-raw’ or ‘tab-processed’).

Returns:

  • Style dictionary for the raw plot container.

  • Style dictionary for the processed plot container.

Return type:

A tuple containing

app.components.CheckboxRenderer(params=None)[source]#

Custom Cell Renderer components for Dash AG Grid.

Note: These Python components define the structure. Corresponding JavaScript functions must be added to the assets folder to handle user interactions (button clicks, checkbox changes) within the grid cells and potentially trigger Dash callbacks via cellRendererData or other methods. See: https://dash.plotly.com/dash-ag-grid/cell-renderer-components

app.components.renderers.CheckboxRenderer(params=None)[source]#

Modal

Utilities#

Utility functions for ThermogramForge application.

This package exports various helper functions used across the application, primarily related to data processing and visualization generation.

app.utils.preprocess_thermogram_data(df)[source]#

Preprocesses a single thermogram sample DataFrame.

Standardizes column names to ‘Temperature’ and ‘dCp’ (assuming they are the first two columns if not named correctly). Converts these columns to numeric types, coercing errors to NaN. Drops rows with NaN in either column. Sorts the data by ‘Temperature’ and resets the index.

Parameters:

df (DataFrame) – Raw DataFrame representing a single thermogram sample.

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

A processed DataFrame with standardized ‘Temperature’ and ‘dCp’ columns, sorted, cleaned, and with a reset index. Returns an empty DataFrame with the expected columns if preprocessing fails or results in no valid data.

Raises:

ValueError – If the input is not a DataFrame.

app.utils.extract_samples(df)[source]#

Extracts and preprocesses individual samples from a multi-column DataFrame.

Assumes samples are stored in paired columns, typically named ‘T[SampleID]’ for temperature and ‘SampleID’ for the corresponding dCp values (or similar patterns identifiable by regex).

Parameters:

df (DataFrame) – The input DataFrame, potentially containing multiple sample pairs.

Return type:

Dict[str, DataFrame]

Returns:

A dictionary where keys are the extracted sample IDs (str) and values are the fully preprocessed DataFrames (containing ‘Temperature’ and ‘dCp’ columns, cleaned and sorted) for each sample. Returns an empty dictionary if no valid sample pairs are found or processed successfully.

app.utils.interpolate_thermogram(df, temp_grid=None, num_points=500)[source]#

Interpolates thermogram dCp values onto a specified or uniform temperature grid.

Uses linear interpolation via numpy.interp.

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) – DataFrame containing numeric ‘Temperature’ and ‘dCp’ columns. Data should ideally be preprocessed and sorted by Temperature.

  • temp_grid (Optional[ndarray]) – Optional 1D NumPy array representing the desired target temperature grid for interpolation. If None, a uniform grid with num_points between the min and max temperature of the input df will be generated.

  • num_points (int) – The number of points to use for the uniform grid generation if temp_grid is None. Ignored if temp_grid is provided.

Return type:

Optional[DataFrame]

Returns:

A new DataFrame with ‘Temperature’ (from the target grid) and interpolated ‘dCp’ columns. Returns None if interpolation fails, input is invalid, or the temperature range cannot be determined.

app.utils.find_duplicate_ids(layout)[source]#

Find duplicate IDs in a Dash layout.

Parameters:

layout (Any) – The Dash layout object to check

Return type:

Dict[str, int]

Returns:

A dict mapping duplicate IDs to their count

app.utils.create_thermogram_figure(df, title='Thermogram Analysis')[source]#

Creates a simple thermogram visualization.

Parameters:

  • df (Optional[pd.DataFrame]) – DataFrame containing thermogram data with ‘Temperature’ and ‘dCp’ columns. If None or empty, an empty figure with a message is returned.

  • title (str) – The title for the plot. Defaults to “Thermogram Analysis”.

Returns:

A Plotly Figure object representing the thermogram.

Return type:

go.Figure

app.utils.create_data_preview(df, max_rows=10)[source]#

Creates a data preview component with summary and table.

Parameters:

  • df (Optional[DataFrame]) – DataFrame to preview. Expects ‘Temperature’ and ‘dCp’ columns for the summary section. If None or empty, shows a message.

  • max_rows (int) – Maximum number of rows to show in the preview table. Defaults to 10.

Return type:

Div

Returns:

A Dash html.Div component containing the data summary and table preview.

app.utils.create_baseline_figure(df, baseline_df, title, endpoints)[source]#

Creates a figure showing baseline subtraction with two subplots.

Parameters:

  • df (Optional[pd.DataFrame]) – Original DataFrame with ‘Temperature’ and ‘dCp’ columns.

  • baseline_df (Optional[pd.DataFrame]) – DataFrame with baseline-subtracted data, expecting ‘Temperature’, ‘dCp_baseline’, and ‘dCp_subtracted’ columns.

  • title (str) – The title for the plot.

  • endpoints (Optional[Tuple[float, float]]) – Tuple of (lower_temp, upper_temp) for baseline endpoints. If None, vertical lines are not drawn.

Returns:

A Plotly Figure object with two subplots: raw data + baseline,

and baseline-subtracted data. Returns an empty figure with a message on error or if input data is invalid.

Return type:

go.Figure

app.utils.create_comparison_figure(samples, mode='raw', title='Thermogram Comparison')[source]#

Creates a comparison figure of multiple thermogram samples.

Parameters:

  • samples (Optional[Dict[str, Optional[pd.DataFrame]]]) – Dictionary where keys are sample_ids (str) and values are DataFrames. Each DataFrame should contain ‘Temperature’ and ‘dCp’. If mode is ‘baseline’, it should also contain ‘dCp_subtracted’. If None or empty, returns an empty figure with a message.

  • mode (str) – Comparison mode. Options: ‘raw’, ‘baseline’, ‘normalized’. Defaults to ‘raw’.

  • title (str) – The title for the plot. Defaults to “Thermogram Comparison”.

Returns:

A Plotly Figure object comparing the samples. Returns an empty

figure with a message if input is invalid or no valid samples are found.

Return type:

go.Figure

Utility functions supporting baseline calculations and data lookup.

These helpers are primarily used by baseline-related callbacks.

app.utils.baseline_utils.find_value_at_temp(df, temp, temp_col='Temperature', val_col='dCp')[source]#

Finds the value in val_col closest to the given temperature in temp_col.

Uses the absolute difference to find the row with the temperature closest to the target temp and returns the corresponding value from val_col.

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) – DataFrame containing temperature and value data.

  • temp (float) – Target temperature.

  • temp_col (str) – Name of the temperature column.

  • val_col (str) – Name of the value column.

Return type:

Optional[float]

Returns:

The value from val_col corresponding to the temperature closest to the target temp (as float), or None if columns are missing, not numeric, or an error occurs.

app.utils.baseline_utils.calculate_linear_baseline(lower_temp, lower_val, upper_temp, upper_val)[source]#

Calculates the slope and intercept of a linear baseline between two points.

Parameters:

  • lower_temp (float) – Temperature (x-coordinate) of the lower baseline point.

  • lower_val (float) – Value (y-coordinate, e.g., dCp) of the lower baseline point.

  • upper_temp (float) – Temperature (x-coordinate) of the upper baseline point.

  • upper_val (float) – Value (y-coordinate, e.g., dCp) of the upper baseline point.

Return type:

Tuple[float, float]

Returns:

A tuple containing the slope (m) and intercept (b) of the line (y = mx + b). Returns (0.0, lower_val) if temperatures are identical or too close to avoid division by zero, effectively creating a horizontal baseline segment.

Data processing utilities for thermogram analysis.

Includes functions for preprocessing raw data, extracting individual samples from multi-sample files, and interpolating data onto a defined grid.

app.utils.data_processing.preprocess_thermogram_data(df)[source]#

Preprocesses a single thermogram sample DataFrame.

Standardizes column names to ‘Temperature’ and ‘dCp’ (assuming they are the first two columns if not named correctly). Converts these columns to numeric types, coercing errors to NaN. Drops rows with NaN in either column. Sorts the data by ‘Temperature’ and resets the index.

df (DataFrame) – Raw DataFrame representing a single thermogram sample.

Return type:

DataFrame
